records are received, which again, have been requested. I further explained

before releasing PIP payments as he can determine who receives what amount
of the available benefits. He can not simply release all benefits to a
single provider when you have numerous providers and already $30k just
between 2 of them. I have sent this information over to him to review as
well as the statement that a civil suit is being 'following' or 'filed' on
your behalf. He will reach out to you to discuss this matter further.

On Tue, 14 Feb 2023 12:36:13 -0500, Sarena Tuttle emailed Muhammad Alif:

Case: Muhammad-Alif-MVA-12-09-2022
Client: Muhammad Alif
__Re: Fw: Filing a lawsuit__
CC:
Good morning Mo,
 Thank you for the email. While we understand your concern, filing suit
is not a proper process for your claims at this time. The Bodily Injury
Carrier for your claims have accepted liability and we are simply awaiting
you to complete treatment. Once you have completed treatment and all of
your records & bills have been obtained, we will proceed with the proper
Demand Process. IF during the negotiation phase of the claim, your bodily
injury carrier is not willing to make a reasonable offer, your attorney,
Aaron Whaley, will review the file for litigation. Please understand that
litigation is a very expensive and lengthy process and should not be taken
lightly, at this time, we will not be filing a civil suit. If you have any
other questions, please do not hesitate to contact us directly to discuss
them in further detail.
Sarena M. Tuttle

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Called Client about Admin situation on MRs - Client asked about Claim & what his options are - Referred him to have a sit down with AW to go over everything as I have explained to the best of my ability - Client wants to pick & choose which injuries are attributed to which incident - Explained to Client again that he does not get to pick & choose - Explained that the Insurance companies will look at the extent of the damage to the vehicle & decide which injuries are attributable - This claim has minimal to minor damage, where as his 1st accident was minor to moderate damage, making his injuries more attributable to the 1st accident. - Explained to Client that AW is doing his best to attribute injuries & damages appropriately but can not force the insurance to change position without additional/new information - Further explained that additional/new information can only be obtained by settlement of the 1st accident and concrete decision on which injuries are related/not related - Client expressed better understanding after analogy of assault (I hit him with a bat & pole, month later Gail open hand smacks him. He does not complain of back injury when I hit him, but does after Gail smacks him. Gail's insurance will say his back injury is due to my assault not Gail's regardless of when he complained of back pain)

__Date & Time__: December 19 2024

Settlement Negotiation Call with Progressive Adjuster Natasha Fortune:

Aaron Whaley spoke with Natasha Fortune (Progressive Insurance, 518-560-3853) regarding settlement negotiations for Mr. Alif's claim.

KEY POINTS:
- Progressive's final offer: $3,500 (confirmed as highest amount available)
- Previous offer clarification: Last offer on record was $3,250 (not $3,800 as previously thought)
- Aaron has authority to negotiate up to $5,000 but will need to consult with client regarding the $3,500 offer
- Treatment records concern: Aaron noted that the 813 pages of documentation do not solely pertain to treatment prior to the accident in question - will review records further before proceeding
- Natasha requested courtesy notice if legal action is filed

NEXT STEPS:
1. Aaron will discuss the $3,500 settlement offer with client
2. Review treatment records to address Progressive's concerns about pre-existing treatment
3. If filing legal action, send courtesy notice to Natasha Fortune
